books.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II

chapters.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:1
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:2
verses.text: This book can hardly be said to form part of a dialogue.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:3
verses.text: It is rather an argument from Scripture to prove the point of the Augustinian arguer, Atticus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:4
verses.text: From the fourth chapter onwards it consists, like the last five chapters of Book I.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:5
verses.text: , of a chain of Scripture texts, taken from the New Testament and the Prophets, to show the universality of sin, and thus to refute the Pelagian assertion that a man can be without sin if he wills.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:6
verses.text: We shall, therefore, give, as in the previous case, a list of the texts and the first words of them, only giving Jerome's words where he introduces some original remark of his own, or some noteworthy comment.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:7
verses.text: The Pelagian begins by reiterating the dilemma: If the commandments are given to be obeyed, then man can be without sin; if he is, by his creation, such that he must be a sinner, then God, not he, is the author of sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:8
verses.text: To the argument that sacrifices are enjoined for sins of ignorance, he replies by appealing from the Old Testament to the New, which leads to a discussion (2, 3) on St.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:9
verses.text: Paul's description of the conflict with sin, in Romans vii.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:10
verses.text: Paul, it is argued, speaks not as a sinner, but as a man, and thus confesses the sinfulness of humanity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:11
verses.text: That men may be without ingrained vice is possible; that they can be without sin is not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:12
verses.text: This leads the Augustinian, Atticus, resuming his list of testimonies, to the fact that, though men are found who are righteous as avoiding wickedness (κακία), yet none is without sin (ἀναμάρτητος ).

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:13
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:14
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:15
verses.text: One who speaks of himself as "holy," yet confesses his transgression.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:16
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:17
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:18
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:19
verses.text: Explains this, "The righteous falls, but sins again".

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:21
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:22
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:23

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:26

verses.text: This is said by Christ in the person of humanity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:94
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:95

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:104
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:105

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:107
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:108
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:109
verses.text: "There be righteous men unto whom it happeneth according to the work of the wicked;" that is, God sees evil where we do not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:110
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:111
verses.text: "However much a man may labor, yet he shall not find it;" and  ix.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:112
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:113
verses.text: There is one event to all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:114
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:115
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:116
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:117
verses.text: "Dead flies cause the ointment to stink;" That is, almost everyone is defiled by heresy or other faults.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:118
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:119
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:120
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:121
verses.text: Judgement must begin at the house of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:122
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:123
verses.text: There are four emotions which agitate mankind, two relating to the present, two to the future; two to good, and two to evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:124
verses.text: There is sorrow, called in Greek λύπη, and joy, in Greek χαρά or ἡδονή, although many translate the latter word by voluptas, pleasure; the one of which is referred to evil, the other to good.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:125
verses.text: And we go too far if we rejoice over such things as we ought not, as, for example, riches, power, distinctions, the bad fortune of enemies, or their death; or, on the other hand, if we are tortured with grief on account of present evils, adversity, exile, poverty, weakness, and the death of kindred, all of which is forbidden by the Apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:126
verses.text: And again, if we covet those things which we consider good, inheritance, distinctions, unvaried prosperity, bodily health, and the like, in the possession of which we rejoice and find enjoyment; or if we fear those things which we deem adverse.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:127
verses.text: Now, according to the Stoics, Zeno that is to say and Chrysippus, it is possible for a perfect man to be free from these emotions; according to the Peripatetics, it is difficult and even impossible, an opinion which has the constant support of all Scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:128
verses.text: Hence Josephus, the historian of the Maccabees, said that the emotions can be subdued and governed, not extirpated, and Cicero's five books of "Tusculan Disputations" are full of these discussions.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:129
verses.text: According to the Apostle, the weakness of the body and spiritual hosts of wickedness in the heavenly places fight against us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:130
verses.text: And the same writer tells us that the works of the flesh and the works of the spirit are manifest, and these are contrary the one to the other, so that we do not the things that we would.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:131
verses.text: If we do not what we would, but what we would not, how can you say that a man can be without sin if he chooses? You see that neither an Apostle, nor any believer can perform what he wishes".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:132
verses.text: Love covereth a multitude of sins," not so much sins of the past as sins of the present, that we may not sin any more while the love of God abideth in us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:133
verses.text: Wherefore it is said concerning the woman that was a sinner,"Her sins which are many are forgiven her, for she loved much".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:134
verses.text: And this shows us that the doing what we wish does not depend merely upon our own power, but upon the assistance which God in His mercy gives to our will.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:135
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:136
verses.text: The quotations from Scripture are now continued:  In 1 John i.

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:138
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:139

verses.text: "The wicked walk on every side," and  James iv.

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:600
verses.text: God giveth grace to the humble.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:601

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:603
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:604
verses.text: Let rottenness enter into my bones, if only I may rest, etc.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:605
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:606
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:607
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:608
verses.text: Joshua is represented as clothed in filthy garments, and is freed through God's mercy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:609
verses.text: But Jovinian's heir says "I am quite free from sin, I have no filthy garments, I am governed by my own will, I am greater than an Apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:610
verses.text: The Apostle does what he would not, and what he would he does not; but I do what I will, and what I would not I do not: the kingdom of heaven has been prepared for me, or rather I have by my virtuous life prepared it for myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:611
verses.text: Adam was subject to punishment, and so are others who think themselves guilty after the similitude of Adam's transgressions; I and my crew alone have nothing to fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:612
verses.text: Other men shut up in their cells and who never see women, because, poor creatures! they do not listen to my words, are tormented with desire: crowds of women may surround me, I feel no stirring of concupiscence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:613
verses.text: For to me may be applied thewords, 'Holy stones are rolled upon the ground,' and the reason why I am insensible to the attraction of sin is that in the power of free will I carry Christ's trophy about with me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:614
verses.text: But let us listen to God proclaiming by the mouth of Isaiah: "O my people, they which call thee happy cause thee to err, and destroy the way of thy paths".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:615
verses.text: Who is the greatest subverter of the people of God—he who, relying on the power of free choice, despises the help of the Creator, and is satisfied with following his own will, or he who dreads to be judged by the details of the Lord's commandments? To men of this sort, Godsays, "Woe unto you that are wise in your own eyes, and prudent in your own sight".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:616
verses.text: Isaiah, if we follow the Hebrew, lamentsand says, "Woe is me because I have been silent, because I am a man of unclean lips: and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips, for mine eyes have seen the Lord of Hosts".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:617
verses.text: He for his meritorious and virtuous life enjoyed the sight of God, and conscious of his sins confessed that he had unclean lips.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:618
verses.text: Not that he had said anything repugnant to the will of God, but because, either from fear, or from a deep sense of shame, he had beensilent, and had not reproved the errors of the people so freely as a prophet should.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:619
verses.text: When do we sinners rebuke offenders, we who flatter wealth and accept the persons of sinners for the sake of filthy lucre? for we shall hardly say that we speak with perfect frankness to men of whose assistance we stand in need.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:620
verses.text: Suppose that we do not such things as they, suppose we keep ourselves from every form of sin; to refrain from speaking the truth is certainly sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:621
verses.text: In the Septuagint, however, we do not find the words "because I have been silent," but "because I was pricked," that is with the consciousness of sin; and thus the words of theprophet are fulfilled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:622
verses.text: "My life was turned into misery while I was pierced by the thorn".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:623
verses.text: He was pricked by the thorn of sin: you are decked with the flowers of virtue".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:624
verses.text: The moon shall be ashamed, and the sun confounded, when the Lord shall punish the host of heaven on high".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:625
verses.text: This is explained by another passage".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:626
verses.text: Even the stars are unclean in His sight," and again, "He chargeth His angels with folly".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:627
verses.text: The moon is ashamed, the sun is confounded, and the sky covered with sackcloth, and shall we fearlessly and joyously, as though we were free from all sin, face the majesty of the Judge, when the mountains shall melt away, that is, all who are lifted up by pride, and all the host of the heavens, whether they be stars, or angelic powers, when the heavens shall be rolled together as a scroll, and all their host shall fade away like leaves?  The argument is now carried on mostly by the quotation of passages from the prophets:  25.

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:630
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:631

verses.text: It will come down in Edom".

verses.text: How much more is there wrath against sin on earth! Edom means blood, which cannot inherit the kingdom (1 Cor.

Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:645
verses.text: Jerusalem is perfect in beauty; yet  Ezek.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:646
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:647
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:648
verses.text: Her salvation is not of merit but of mercy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:649
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:650
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:651
verses.text: Though he cleanse, yet will he not make thee innocent.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:652
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:653
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:654
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:655
verses.text: I am not worthy—because I persecuted.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:656
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:657
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:658
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:659
verses.text: When pardoned, Jerusalem will still remember her sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:660
verses.text: Let us confess with shame that these are the utterances of men who have already won their reward; sinners upon earth, and still in our frail and mortal bodies let us adopt the language of the saints in heaven who have even been endowed with incorruption and immortality".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:661
verses.text: And ye say the way of the Lord is not equal, when your ways are not equal".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:662
verses.text: It is Pharisaic pride to attribute to the injustice of the Creator sins which are due to our own will, and to slander His righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:663
verses.text: The sons of Zadok, the priests of the spiritual temple, that is the Church,go not out to the people in their ministerial robes, lest by human intercourse they may lose their holiness and be defiled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:664
verses.text: And do you suppose that you, in the thick of the throng, and an ordinary individual, are pure?  26.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:665
verses.text: Let us hastily run through the prophet Jeremiah:  Jerem.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:666
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:667
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:668
verses.text: Is there any that doeth justly, etc.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:669
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:670
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:671
verses.text: God rejects the sacrifices, because of the worshippers' evil lives.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:672
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:673
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:674
verses.text: Can the Ethiopian change his skin?  27.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:675
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:676
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:677
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:678
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:679
verses.text: Otherwise Jeremiah could only say, as in the text next quoted,  xx.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:680
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:681
verses.text: Cursed be the day wherein I was born, etc.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:682
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:683
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:684
verses.text: Am I a God at hand, etc.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:685
verses.text: So conscious is he of God's power.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:686
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:687
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:688
verses.text: God, not they themselves, will plant them, etc.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:689
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:690
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:691
verses.text: Jeremiah needed the help of Ahikam.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:692
verses.text: How much more do we need that of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:693
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:694
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:695
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:696
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:697
verses.text: The promise of the new covenant.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:698
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:699
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:700
verses.text: The children of Israel have perpetually done evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:701
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:702
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:703
verses.text: Yet Jeremiah himself trembled before Zedekiah.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:704
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:705
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:706
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:707
verses.text: Fear not, O Jacob, for I am with thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:708
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:709
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:710
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:711
verses.text: "We have taken us horns by our own strength".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:712
verses.text: These are the boasts of heretics.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:713
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:714
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:715
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:716
verses.text: His strength (Moab's) is by no means according to his arrogance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:717
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:718
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:719
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:720
verses.text: Men's sin will only be abolished because God is gracious to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:721
verses.text: If you will abandon your assertions of natural ability, I will concede that your whole contention stands good, but only by the gift of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:722
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:723
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:724
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:725
verses.text: It is good that a man should quietly wait for the salvation of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:726
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:727
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:728
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:729
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:730
verses.text: The Most High ruleth in the kingdom of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:731
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:732
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:733
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:734
verses.text: He raiseth up the poor out of the dust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:735
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:736
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:737
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:738
verses.text: He doeth what He will in heaven and in earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:739
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:740
verses.text: 17, which say that Antiochus Epiphanes had power to overthrow the Temple, "because of the multitude of sins," are quoted in connection with the confessions of Daniel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:741
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:742
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:743
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:744
verses.text: "We have sinned and dealt perversely," which is shown by  20.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:745
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:746
verses.text: , to be a personal, not only a national confession.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:747
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:748
verses.text: The prophecy of the seventy weeks shows that the prophet looked to God alone for the establishment of righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:749
verses.text: So then, until that end shall come, and this corruptible and mortal shall put on incorruption and immortality, we must be liable to sin; not, as you falsely say, owing to the fault of our nature and creation, but through the frailty and fickleness of human will, which varies from moment to moment; because God alone changeth not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:750
verses.text: You ask in what respects Abel, Enoch, Joshua the son of Nun, or Elisha, and the rest of the saints have sinned.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:751
verses.text: There is no need to look for a knot in a bulrush; I freely confess I do not know; and I only wish that, when sins are manifest, I might still be silent".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:752
verses.text: I know nothing against myself," says St.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:753
verses.text: Paul, "yet am I not hereby justified".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:754
verses.text: "Man looketh on the outward appearance, but the Lord looketh on the heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:755
verses.text: Before Him no man is justified.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book II 1:756
verses.text: And so Paul says confidently,"All have sinned, and come short of the glory of God"; and"God hath shut up all under sin that He may have mercy upon all"; and similarly in other passages which we have repeated again and again.
